        nasko: Uh oh! This issue still open and hasn't been updated in the last 14 days. This is a serious vulnerability, and we want to ensure that there's progress. Could you please leave an update with the current status and any potential blockers?<span class="line"><!---->nasko: Uh oh! This issue still open and hasn't been updated in the last 14 days. This is a serious vulnerability, and we want to ensure that there's progress. Could you please leave an update with the current status and any potential blockers?<!----></span><br><br>If you're not the right owner for this issue, could you please remove yourself as soon as possible or help us find the right one?<span class="line"><!---->If you're not the right owner for this issue, could you please remove yourself as soon as possible or help us find the right one?<!----></span><br><br>If the issue is fixed or you can't reproduce it, please close the bug. Could you please leave an update with the current status and any potential blockers?<span class="line"><!---->jarhar: Uh oh! This issue still open and hasn't been updated in the last 14 days. Could you please leave an update with the current status and any potential blockers?<!----></span><br><br>If you're not the right owner for this issue, could you please remove yourself as soon as possible or help us find the right one?<span class="line"><!---->If you're not the right owner for this issue, could you please remove yourself as soon as possible or help us find the right one?<!----></span><br><br>If the issue is fixed or you can't reproduce it, please close the bug. However, the renderer process shouldn't have<span class="line"><!---->network request debugging. However, the renderer process shouldn't have<!----></span><br>access to raw headers, because then it would have access to cross-origin<span class="line"><!---->access to raw headers, because then it would have access to cross-origin<!----></span><br>cookies, HttpOnly cookies, etc.<span class="line"><!---->cookies, HttpOnly cookies, etc.<!----></span><br><br>In order to fix this security issue but still make headers debuggable<span class="line"><!---->In order to fix this security issue but still make headers debuggable<!----></span><br>for DevTools, a trusted channel to the DevTools frontend which goes<span class="line"><!---->for DevTools, a trusted channel to the DevTools frontend which goes<!----></span><br>through the browser process instead of the renderer process was made,<span class="line"><!---->through the browser process instead of the renderer process was made,<!----></span><br>and I plumbed an ID, called "devtools_request_id", through this channel<span class="line"><!---->and I plumbed an ID, called "devtools_request_id", through this channel<!----></span><br>in<span class="line"><!---->in<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/648335<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/648335"><!---->crrev.com/648335<!----></a> so DevTools has required context to debug the<span class="line"><!----> so DevTools has required context to debug the<!----></span><br>network request.<span class="line"><!---->network request.<!----></span><br><br>Now that DevTools doesn't need report_raw_headers in order to debug<span class="line"><!---->Now that DevTools doesn't need report_raw_headers in order to debug<!----></span><br>network headers anymore, we're removing it along with the related raw<span class="line"><!---->network headers anymore, we're removing it along with the related raw<!----></span><br>header code in order to simplify things and strengthen security.<span class="line"><!---->header code in order to simplify things and strengthen security.<!----></span><br><br>I waited longer than I should have to do this because shared worker<span class="line"><!---->I waited longer than I should have to do this because shared worker<!----></span><br>request debugging still relies on report_raw_headers, but in light of<span class="line"><!---->request debugging still relies on report_raw_headers, but in light of<!----></span><br>recent security issues, in addition to lack of perceived interest in<span class="line"><!---->recent security issues, in addition to lack of perceived interest in<!----></span><br>shared worker request debugging, and *significant* complexity of<span class="line"><!---->shared worker request debugging, and *significant* complexity of<!----></span><br>updating shared worker code, I am going for it now.<span class="line"><!---->updating shared worker code, I am going for it now.<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1142014<span         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        As part of the extension discussions here, we also investigated a feature to prevent different extensions from sharing a process with each other in <span class="line"><!---->As part of the extension discussions here, we also investigated a feature to prevent different extensions from sharing a process with each other in <!----></span>issue 1209417<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1209417" title="Add Feature for all extensions to require locked processes"><!---->issue 1209417<!----></a>.  We monitored the performance impact and have just enabled it by default on M92 stable!<span class="line"><!---->.  We monitored the performance impact and have just enabled it by default on M92 stable!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

&lt;<!----></span>jarhar@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/jarhar@chromium.org"><!---->jarhar@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Tue responseReceived.emittedExtraInfo<!----></span><br><br>Design doc which discusses more background and other options:<span class="line"><!---->Design doc which discusses more background and other options:<!----></span><br>https://docs.google.com/document/d/1NM30Wg_aM3-RFZaD_lQuWQj8my8XoR9YpMi60QH1lHU/edit<a class="undefined" target="_blank" new responseReceived.emittedExtraInfo flag indicates whether or not<span class="line"><!---->The new responseReceived.emittedExtraInfo flag indicates whether or not<!----></span><br>requestWillBeSentExtraInfo and responseReceivedExtraInfo events were<span class="line"><!---->requestWillBeSentExtraInfo and responseReceivedExtraInfo events were<!----></span><br>also emitted for the same network request.<span class="line"><!---->also emitted for the same network request.<!----></span><br><br>With this knowledge, CDP clients like puppeteer can know whether or not<span class="line"><!---->With this knowledge, CDP clients like puppeteer can know whether or not<!----></span><br>to wait for the pairing of responseReceived and ExtraInfo events.<span class="line"><!---->to wait for the pairing of responseReceived and ExtraInfo events.<!----></span><br>Without this knowledge, they currently can't expose the information in<span class="line"><!---->Without this knowledge, they currently can't expose the information in<!----></span><br>ExtraInfo events because they would get hung up waiting for ExtraInfo<span class="line"><!---->ExtraInfo events because they would get hung up waiting for ExtraInfo<!----></span><br>events for requests which don't emit them.<span class="line"><!---->events for requests which don't emit them.<!----></span><br>The information in ExtraInfo events is very important because they have<span class="line"><!---->The information in ExtraInfo events is very important because they have<!----></span><br>significantly more accurate HTTP headers, among other things.<span class="line"><!---->significantly more accurate HTTP headers, among other things.<!----></span><br><br>This also addresses a regression for puppeteer when I removed<span class="line"><!---->This also addresses a regression for puppeteer when I removed<!----></span><br>report_raw_headers from ResourceRequest in <span class="line"><!---->report_raw_headers from ResourceRequest in <!----></span>http://crrev.com/908142<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://crrev.com/908142"><!---->http://crrev.com/908142<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br>Puppeteer relies on report_raw_headers because it can't lazily wait for<span class="line"><!---->Puppeteer relies on report_raw_headers because it can't lazily wait for<!----></span><br>ExtraInfo events like the DevTools frontend does. However, with this new<span class="line"><!---->ExtraInfo events like the DevTools frontend does. However, with this new<!----></span><br>flag, Puppeteer can actually start using ExtraInfo events.<span class="line"><!---->flag, Puppeteer can actually start using ExtraInfo events.<!----></span><br><br>In order to implement the flag, I am plumbing it through the network<span class="line"><!---->In order to implement the flag, I am plumbing it through the network<!----></span><br>service interface. Alternatively, we could try to guess whether network<span class="line"><!---->service interface. Alternatively, we could try to guess whether network<!----></span><br>service will emit ExtraInfo events, but based on my prototyping I<span class="line"><!---->service will emit ExtraInfo events, but based on my prototyping I<!----></span><br>couldn't get this to work with the limited information we have in the<span class="line"><!---->couldn't get this to work with the limited information we have in the<!----></span><br>renderer process.<span class="line"><!---->renderer process.<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1199865<a class="strike-through" target="_blank"         Description #1 by adetaylor@google.com (Apr 16, 2021)
      <option value="0" selected="">

      Attached is a pre-print paper we've been sent.<span class="line"><!---->Attached is a pre-print paper we've been sent.<!----></span><br><br>From briefly scanning, it says:<span class="line"><!---->From briefly scanning, it says:<!----></span><br><br>* Lumping together multiple origins into a single renderer process is suboptimal, and makes them vulnerable to spectre.js type attacks. I don't think this is news.<span class="line"><!---->* Lumping together multiple origins into a single renderer process is suboptimal, and makes them vulnerable to spectre.js type attacks. I don't think this is news.<!----></span><br>* We also lump together extensions into a single renderer process, and so they were able to steal passwords from LastPass by writing a malicious extension.<span class="line"><!---->* We also lump together extensions into a single renderer process, and so they were able to steal passwords from LastPass by writing a malicious extension.<!----></span><br><br>Nasko, Devlin, it feels to me like this second part *possibly* might merit some countermeasures. Could you take a look?<span class="line"><!---->Nasko, Devlin, it feels to me like this second part *possibly* might merit some countermeasures. Could you take a look?<!----></span><br><br>I understand they aim to publish "within 90 days".<span class="line"><!---->I understand they aim to publish "within 90 days".<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Note: I haven't had a chance to read the paper, so just going off the question from adetaylor@ in c#0.<span class="line"><!---->Note: I haven't had a chance to read the paper, so just going off the question from adetaylor@ in c#0.<!----></span><br><br>TL;DR: Nothing new here.<span class="line"><!---->TL;DR: Nothing new here.<!----></span><br><br>> * We also lump together extensions into a single renderer process, and so they were able to steal passwords from LastPass by writing a malicious extension.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; * We also lump together extensions into a single renderer process, and so they were able to steal passwords from LastPass by writing a malicious extension.<!----></span><br><br>This is really the same as the previous bullet.  At their core here, extensions are very akin to origins in this situation.  Lumping them together makes them vulnerable to spectre-like attacks.  And using LastPass as an example isn't really different than using<span class="line"><!---->This is really the same as the previous bullet.  At their core here, extensions are very akin to origins in this situation.  Lumping them together makes them vulnerable to spectre-like attacks.  And using LastPass as an example isn't really different than using<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>passwords.google.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://passwords.google.com"><!---->passwords.google.com<!----></a> - in both cases, if we happen to lump origins (either web pages or extensions) together, there's a risk of leaking data.<span class="line"><!----> - in both cases, if we happen to lump origins (either web pages or extensions) together, there's a risk of leaking data.<!----></span><br><br>We've chatted in the past about different ways we might potentially address this - essentially, trying to be "smarter" about which extensions we join together.  We've come up with a few different ideas - grouping extensions based on install source (e.g. policy installed together, component together, user-installed together), allowing extensions to specify a key in their manifest (`"isolate_me": true`), etc.  We haven't found anything that is scalable and also solved the majority of cases, so haven't invested heavily in it (though I'd still be supportive).<span class="line"><!---->We've chatted in the past about different ways we might potentially address this - essentially, trying to be "smarter" about which extensions we join together.  We've come up with a few different ideas - grouping extensions based on install source (e.g. policy installed together, component together, user-installed together), allowing extensions to specify a key in their manifest (`"isolate_me": true`), etc.  We haven't found anything that is scalable and also solved the majority of cases, so haven't invested heavily in it (though I'd still be supportive).<!----></span><br><br>I also vaguely thought we were looking at different ways we could identify "high value" origins in general, and avoid having those share processes (or be stricter about what's allowed to share with them) - is there still work on that front?  If so, it seems like we could just include extensions in that mechanism (and, ideally, things would "just work").<span class="line"><!---->I also vaguely thought we were looking at different ways we could identify "high value" origins in general, and avoid having those share processes (or be stricter about what's allowed to share with them) - is there still work on that front?  If so, it seems like we could just include extensions in that mechanism (and, ideally, things would "just work").<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I haven't read the full paper in depth yet, but skimming over there is one worrisome part - they claim they can extract HttpOnly cookies from the renderer process memory:<span class="line"><!---->I haven't read the full paper in depth yet, but skimming over there is one worrisome part - they claim they can extract HttpOnly cookies from the renderer process memory:<!----></span><br><br>"Next, as the user was previously authenticated through the university’s single sign-on screen, the housing’s portal iframe automatically accessed the university’s HttpOnly login cookie,  ringing it to the memory address space of the renderer process, without any user interaction."<span class="line"><!---->"Next, as the user was previously authenticated through the university’s single sign-on screen, the housing’s portal iframe automatically accessed the university’s HttpOnly login cookie,  ringing it to the memory address space of the renderer process, without any user interaction."<!----></span><br><br>If this is correct, then we likely have a bug on our hands as we don't allow renderers to access HttpOnly cookies.<span class="line"><!---->If this is correct, then we likely have a bug on our hands as we don't allow renderers to access HttpOnly cookies.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I also haven't read the full paper yet, but I'm curious if we could ask the authors for deanonymized links to their code?  The paper already includes all the authors' names, so I'm assuming they aren't worried about anonymity w.r.t. Chrome, and it might be useful for us to try out some of the links they mention (e.g., <span class="line"><!---->I also haven't read the full paper yet, but I'm curious if we could ask the authors for deanonymized links to their code?  The paper already includes all the authors' names, so I'm assuming they aren't worried about anonymity w.r.t. Chrome, and it might be useful for us to try out some of the links they mention (e.g., <!----></span>https://web.dpt.uni.edu/∼user/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://web.dpt.uni.edu/∼user/"><!---->https://web.dpt.uni.edu/∼user/<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> as we investigate this in more detail.<span class="line"><!----> as we investigate this in more detail.<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>+1 to everything Devlin said in <span class="line"><!---->+1 to everything Devlin said in <!----></span>#c3<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c3"><!---->#c3<!----></a>.  We've considered various ways of grouping different kinds of extensions in separate processes (privileges, source, etc.), but this hasn't been prioritized so far.  I thought we had a bug filed for that, but so far I can't find it.  We will soon have a new mechanism with SiteInstanceGroups (<span class="line"><!---->.  We've considered various ways of grouping different kinds of extensions in separate processes (privileges, source, etc.), but this hasn't been prioritized so far.  I thought we had a bug filed for that, but so far I can't find it.  We will soon have a new mechanism with SiteInstanceGroups (<!----></span>issue 1195535<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1195535" title="Implement SiteInstance groups"><!---->issue 1195535<!----></a>), which might allow doing this quite easily.<span class="line"><!---->), which might allow doing this quite easily.<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>Re: avoiding process sharing for "high-value" origins within a particular site: in general, our hands are tied by document.domain compatibility, but we've recently shipped Origin-Agent-Cluster (<span class="line"><!---->Re: avoiding process sharing for "high-value" origins within a particular site: in general, our hands are tied by document.domain compatibility, but we've recently shipped Origin-Agent-Cluster (<!----></span>https://web.dev/origin-agent-cluster/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://web.dev/origin-agent-cluster/"><!---->https://web.dev/origin-agent-cluster/<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> M89+) which allows origins to opt-in to origin-level (rather than site-level) isolation (and willingly opt out of using document.domain).  Origins can also hint at this and get stronger protection with COOP+COEP headers (<span class="line"><!----> M89+) which allows origins to opt-in to origin-level (rather than site-level) isolation (and willingly opt out of using document.domain).  Origins can also hint at this and get stronger protection with COOP+COEP headers (<!----></span>https://web.dev/coop-coep/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://web.dev/coop-coep/"><!---->https://web.dev/coop-coep/<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The paper's authors have confirmed that we only leak HttpOnly cookies to the renderer if DevTools had been previously opened.<span class="line"><!---->The paper's authors have confirmed that we only leak HttpOnly cookies to the renderer if DevTools had been previously opened.<!----></span><br><br>Adding some DevTools folks: caseq@, jarhar@, or yangguo@, can you confirm whether this is expected, and share any thoughts about fixing it?  Basically, the paper shared with us here shows how to use Spectre to leak HttpOnly cookies to a same-site cross-origin document in the same process.<span class="line"><!---->Adding some DevTools folks: caseq@, jarhar@, or yangguo@, can you confirm whether this is expected, and share any thoughts about fixing it?  Basically, the paper shared with us here shows how to use Spectre to leak HttpOnly cookies to a same-site cross-origin document in the same process.<!----></span><br><br>I found <span class="line"><!---->I found <!----></span>issue 849483<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=849483" title="DevTools: instrument network events from the browser process"><!---->issue 849483<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>where the description includes "stop routing sensitive data (e.g. HTTP-only cookies) through renderer", so it seems like this is a known issue?  That issue is marked fixed, but with a final comment by jarhar@ "We don't currently have any more plans to move network instrumentation from the renderer process to the browser process", so it's a bit unclear what has and hasn't been fixed, and what the current state of HttpOnly cookies with DevTools is (and whether we need to file a new bug for this).<span class="line"><!---->where the description includes "stop routing sensitive data (e.g. HTTP-only cookies) through renderer", so it seems like this is a known issue?  That issue is marked fixed, but with a final comment by jarhar@ "We don't currently have any more plans to move network instrumentation from the renderer process to the browser process", so it's a bit unclear what has and hasn't been fixed, and what the current state of HttpOnly cookies with DevTools is (and whether we need to file a new bug for this).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        It looks like the <span class="line"><!---->It looks like the <!----></span>issue 849483<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=849483" title="DevTools: instrument network events from the browser process"><!---->issue 849483<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>has been closed a bit prematurely (re-opened that now). While the new instrumentation has actually been implemented, we're apparently still reporting the raw headers to renderer as well. I've no idea why this hasn't been removed back then, but I assume it might have been left temporarily for compatibility reasons (jarhar@ may have more context here). I think we should be able to drop URLResponseHead::raw_request_response_info altogether now.<span class="line"><!---->has been closed a bit prematurely (re-opened that now). While the new instrumentation has actually been implemented, we're apparently still reporting the raw headers to renderer as well. I've no idea why this hasn't been removed back then, but I assume it might have been left temporarily for compatibility reasons (jarhar@ may have more context here). I think we should be able to drop URLResponseHead::raw_request_response_info altogether now.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        HttpOnly cookies should only be sent over the secure Network.*ExtraInfo CDP events, right...?<span class="line"><!---->HttpOnly cookies should only be sent over the secure Network.*ExtraInfo CDP events, right...?<!----></span><br>Upon further inspection, I found that Network.responseReceived actually includes HttpOnly cookies...<span class="line"><!---->Upon further inspection, I found that Network.responseReceived actually includes HttpOnly cookies...<!----></span><br><br>Since we are already excluding cookies for cross origin requests as of <span class="line"><!---->Since we are already excluding cookies for cross origin requests as of <!----></span>issue 868407<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=868407" title="Network panel show &quot;Provisional headers are shown&quot; for all non-same origin requests' request headers"><!---->issue 868407<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>I figured HttpOnly cookies would have also been excluded - I guess I was wrong.<span class="line"><!---->I figured HttpOnly cookies would have also been excluded - I guess I was wrong.<!----></span><br>I think it would make sense to start excluding HttpOnly cookies from Network.responseRecieved now, since we should already be getting them in the secure Network.*ExtraInfo requests.<span class="line"><!---->I think it would make sense to start excluding HttpOnly cookies from Network.responseRecieved now, since we should already be getting them in the secure Network.*ExtraInfo requests.<!----></span><br><br>Removing report_raw_headers, which I created <span class="line"><!---->Removing report_raw_headers, which I created <!----></span>issue 1017836<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1017836" title="Remove report_raw_headers from network::ResourceRequest"><!---->issue 1017836<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>to track, is blocked by <span class="line"><!---->to track, is blocked by <!----></span>issue 1004979<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1004979" title="DevTools: Shared worker main script and subresource requests do not emit Network.*ExtraInfo events"><!---->issue 1004979<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>which is that shared workers aren't fully instrumented like service workers and don't get the ExtraInfo events, which means that they need report_raw_headers in order to get more useful headers.<span class="line"><!---->which is that shared workers aren't fully instrumented like service workers and don't get the ExtraInfo events, which means that they need report_raw_headers in order to get more useful headers.<!----></span><br><br>I started working on shared worker instrumentation but it became an enormous refactor I never quite completed. We could probably just remove report_raw_headers since it's not that likely anyone actually cares about more accurate headers for shared worker requests anyway...<span class="line"><!---->I started working on shared worker instrumentation but it became an enormous refactor I never quite completed. We could probably just remove report_raw_headers since it's not that likely anyone actually cares about more accurate headers for shared worker requests anyway...<!----></span><br><br>tldr:<span class="line"><!---->tldr:<!----></span><br>We can either filter out HttpOnly cookies from Network.responseReceived when report_raw_headers is enabled which shouldn't break anything, OR we could delete report_raw_headers entirely, which could theoretically lose DevTools some headers for shared worker network requests.<span class="line"><!---->We can either filter out HttpOnly cookies from Network.responseReceived when report_raw_headers is enabled which shouldn't break anything, OR we could delete report_raw_headers entirely, which could theoretically lose DevTools some headers for shared worker network requests.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 17<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1199865#c17">Comment 17<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      jarhar@chromium.org<a id="user-link" href="/u/1751994960" title="jarhar@chromium.org"><!---->jarhar@chromium.org<!----></a>

        by

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1199865#c17">Comment 17<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Apr 28, 2021, 11:55 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>

        It looks like disabling report_raw_headers would be more challenging than I thought:<span class="line"><!---->It looks like disabling report_raw_headers would be more challenging than I thought:<!----></span><br>1. Network.responseReceived's securityState and securityDetails appear to only be reported when report_raw_headers is true, so we would either have to report this from the network stack regardless of report_raw_headers, or move it to Network.responseReceivedExtraInfo [1].<span class="line"><!---->1. Network.responseReceived's securityState and securityDetails appear to only be reported when report_raw_headers is true, so we would either have to report this from the network stack regardless of report_raw_headers, or move it to Network.responseReceivedExtraInfo [1].<!----></span><br>2. It appears that the response HTTP status code can change based on report_raw_headers [1]? I suppose we would also need to move that to Network.responseReceivedExtraInfo...<span class="line"><!---->2. It appears that the response HTTP status code can change based on report_raw_headers [1]? I suppose we would also need to move that to Network.responseReceivedExtraInfo...<!----></span><br>3. The last time I checked, due to the way Puppeteer is architected, it doesn't use Network.*ExtraInfo CDP events, which means that it is completely relying on report_raw_headers for just about everything, and removing it would definitely make its users unhappy. The reason it can't use ExtraInfo events is because not every request that chrome "makes" actually includes ExtraInfo events - the ones which don't make it all the way to the network stack or stay in the renderer don't get these events. In order for this to be addressed, Puppeteer should probably be using the CDP Fetch domain or something instead...? Maybe we could work around this by letting Puppeteer use report_raw_headers while making chrome not use report_raw_headers...?<span class="line"><!---->3. The last time I checked, due to the way Puppeteer is architected, it doesn't use Network.*ExtraInfo CDP events, which means that it is completely relying on report_raw_headers for just about everything, and removing it would definitely make its users unhappy. The reason it can't use ExtraInfo events is because not every request that chrome "makes" actually includes ExtraInfo events - the ones which don't make it all the way to the network stack or stay in the renderer don't get these events. In order for this to be addressed, Puppeteer should probably be using the CDP Fetch domain or something instead...? Maybe we could work around this by letting Puppeteer use report_raw_headers while making chrome not use report_raw_headers...?<!----></span><br><br>The other option, which would exclude HttpOnly cookies from the raw response info sent back to the renderer, requires more knowledge of the network stack than I have. It looks like we could filter them out here [2], but I don't know how to take an actual string of header information, parse the cookies out if it, and determine if each cookie was HttpOnly or not...<span class="line"><!---->The other option, which would exclude HttpOnly cookies from the raw response info sent back to the renderer, requires more knowledge of the network stack than I have. It looks like we could filter them out here [2], but I don't know how to take an actual string of header information, parse the cookies out if it, and determine if each cookie was HttpOnly or not...<!----></span><br><br>I also want to make sure I understand the issue completely:<span class="line"><!---->I also want to make sure I understand the issue completely:<!----></span><br><br>> The paper's authors have confirmed that we only leak HttpOnly cookies to the renderer if DevTools had been previously opened.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; The paper's authors have confirmed that we only leak HttpOnly cookies to the renderer if DevTools had been previously opened.<!----></span><br><br>> Basically, the paper shared with us here shows how to use Spectre to leak HttpOnly cookies to a same-site cross-origin document in the same process.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; Basically, the paper shared with us here shows how to use Spectre to leak HttpOnly cookies to a same-site cross-origin document in the same process.<!----></span><br><br>I understand that allowing HttpOnly cookies into the renderer is a problem in and of itself, but what exactly is a "same-site cross-origin document" and how does it affect the scenario? Is HttpOnly cookies in a renderer process for its own site the *only* concern here?<span class="line"><!---->I understand that allowing HttpOnly cookies into the renderer is a problem in and of itself, but what exactly is a "same-site cross-origin document" and how does it affect the scenario? Is HttpOnly cookies in a renderer process for its own site the *only* concern here?<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://test-results.appspot.com/data/layout_results/linux-rel/677426/blink_web_tests%20%28with%20patch%29/layout-test-results/results.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://test-results.appspot.com/data/layout_results/linux-rel/677426/blink_web_tests%20%28with%20patch%29/layout-test-results/results.html"><!---->https://test-results.appspot.com/data/layout_results/linux-rel/677426/blink_web_tests%20%28with%20patch%29/layout-test-results/results.html<!----></a><br>[2] <span class="line"><!---->[2] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:services/network/url_loader.cc;l=339-355;drc=221e331b49dfefadbc6fa40b0c68e6f97606d0b3<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:services/network/url_loader.cc;l=339-355;drc=221e331b49dfefadbc6fa40b0c68e6f97606d0b3"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:services/network/url_loader.cc;l=339-355;drc=221e331b49dfefadbc6fa40b0c68e6f97606d0b3<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        nasko: Uh oh! This issue still open and hasn't been updated in the last 14 days. This is a serious vulnerability, and we want to ensure that there's progress. Could you please leave an update with the current status and any potential blockers?<span class="line"><!---->nasko: Uh oh! This issue still open and hasn't been updated in the last 14 days. Could you please leave an update with the current status and any potential blockers?<!----></span><br><br>If you're not the right owner for this issue, could you please remove yourself as soon as possible or help us find the right one?<span class="line"><!---->If you're not the right owner for this issue, could you please remove yourself as soon as possible or help us find the right one?<!----></span><br><br>If the issue is fixed or you can't reproduce it, please close the bug.         At this point the only issue requiring action on this bug is the leaking of HttpOnly cookies through DevTools, which this bug is already dependent on. Therefore I'll assign this to jarhar@ to resolve once the DevTools issue is fixed or pass along to whoever will work on it.<span class="line"><!---->At this point the only issue requiring action on this bug is the leaking of HttpOnly cookies through DevTools, which this bug is already dependent on. would have access to cross-origin<!----></span><br>cookies, HttpOnly cookies, etc.<span class="line"><!---->cookies, HttpOnly cookies, etc.<!----></span><br><br>In order to fix this security issue but still make headers debuggable<span class="line"><!---->In order to fix this security issue but still make headers debuggable<!----></span><br>for DevTools, a trusted channel to the DevTools frontend which goes<span class="line"><!---->for DevTools, a trusted channel to the DevTools frontend which goes<!----></span><br>through the browser process instead of the renderer process was made,<span <!----></span>crrev.com/648335<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/648335"><!---->crrev.com/648335<!----></a> so DevTools has required context to debug the<span class="line"><!----> so DevTools has required context to debug the<!----></span><br>network request.<span class="line"><!---->network request.<!----></span><br><br>Now that DevTools doesn't need report_raw_headers in order to debug<span class="line"><!---->Now that DevTools doesn't need report_raw_headers in order to debug<!----></span><br>network headers anymore, we're removing it along with the related raw<span class="line"><!---->network headers anymore, we're removing it along with the related raw<!----></span><br>header code in order to simplify things and strengthen security.<span waited longer than I should have to do this because shared worker<!----></span><br>request debugging still relies on report_raw_headers, but in light of<span class="line"><!---->request debugging still relies on report_raw_headers, but in light of<!----></span><br>recent security issues, in addition to lack of perceived interest in<span class="line"><!---->recent security issues, in addition to lack of perceived interest in<!----></span><br>shared worker request debugging, and *significant* complexity of<span class="line"><!---->shared worker request debugging, and *significant*         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        As part of the extension discussions here, we also investigated a feature to prevent different extensions from sharing a process with each other in <span class="line"><!---->As part of the extension discussions here, we also investigated a feature to prevent different extensions from sharing a process with each other in <!----></span>issue 1209417<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1209417" title="Add Feature for all extensions to require locked processes"><!---->issue 1209417<!----></a>.  We monitored the performance impact and have just enabled it by default on M92 stable!<span class="line"><!---->.  We monitored the performance impact and have just enabled it by default on M92 stable!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

new responseReceived.emittedExtraInfo flag indicates whether or not<span class="line"><!---->The new responseReceived.emittedExtraInfo flag indicates whether or not<!----></span><br>requestWillBeSentExtraInfo and responseReceivedExtraInfo events were<span class="line"><!---->requestWillBeSentExtraInfo and responseReceivedExtraInfo events were<!----></span><br>also emitted for the same network request.<span class="line"><!---->also emitted for the same network request.<!----></span><br><br>With this knowledge, CDP clients like puppeteer can know whether or not<span class="line"><!---->With this knowledge, CDP clients like puppeteer can know whether or not<!----></span><br>to wait for the pairing of responseReceived and ExtraInfo events.<span class="line"><!---->to wait for the pairing of responseReceived and ExtraInfo events.<!----></span><br>Without this knowledge, they currently can't expose the information in<span class="line"><!---->Without this knowledge, they currently can't expose the information in<!----></span><br>ExtraInfo events because they would get hung up waiting for ExtraInfo<span class="line"><!---->ExtraInfo events because they would get hung up waiting for ExtraInfo<!----></span><br>events for requests which don't emit them.<span class="line"><!---->events for requests which don't emit them.<!----></span><br>The information in ExtraInfo events is very important because they have<span class="line"><!---->The information in ExtraInfo events is very important because they have<!----></span><br>significantly more accurate HTTP headers, among other things.<span class="line"><!---->significantly more accurate HTTP headers, among other things.<!----></span><br><br>This also addresses a regression for puppeteer when I removed<span class="line"><!---->This also addresses a regression for puppeteer when I removed<!----></span><br>report_raw_headers from ResourceRequest in <span class="line"><!---->report_raw_headers from ResourceRequest in <!----></span>http://crrev.com/908142<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://crrev.com/908142"><!---->http://crrev.com/908142<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br>Puppeteer relies on report_raw_headers because it can't lazily wait for<span class="line"><!---->Puppeteer relies on report_raw_headers because it can't lazily wait for<!----></span><br>ExtraInfo events like the DevTools frontend does. However, with this new<span class="line"><!---->ExtraInfo events like the DevTools frontend does. However, with this new<!----></span><br>flag, Puppeteer can actually start using ExtraInfo events.<span class="line"><!---->flag, Puppeteer can actually start using ExtraInfo events.<!----></span><br><br>In order to implement the flag, I am plumbing it through the network<span class="line"><!---->In order to implement the flag, I am plumbing it through the network<!----></span><br>service interface. Alternatively, we could try to guess whether network<!----></span><br>service will emit ExtraInfo events, but based on my prototyping I<span class="line"><!---->service will emit ExtraInfo events, but based on my prototyping I<!----></span><br>couldn't get this to work with the limited information we have in the<span class="line"><!---->couldn't get this to work with the limited information we have       Attached is a pre-print paper we've been sent.<span class="line"><!---->Attached is a pre-print paper we've been sent.<!----></span><br><br>From briefly scanning, it says:<span class="line"><!---->From briefly scanning, it says:<!----></span><br><br>* Lumping together multiple origins into a single renderer process is suboptimal, and makes them vulnerable to spectre.js type attacks. I don't think this is news.<span class="line"><!---->* Lumping together multiple origins into a single renderer process is suboptimal, and makes them vulnerable to spectre.js type attacks. I don't think this is news.<!----></span><br>* We also lump together extensions into a single renderer process, and so they were able to steal passwords from LastPass by writing a malicious extension.<span class="line"><!---->* We also lump together extensions into a single renderer process, and so they were able to steal passwords from LastPass by writing a malicious extension.<!----></span><br><br>Nasko, Devlin, it feels to me like this second part *possibly* might merit some countermeasures. Could you take a look?<span class="line"><!---->Nasko, Devlin, it feels to me like this second part *possibly* might merit some countermeasures. Could you take a look?<!----></span><br><br>I understand they aim to publish "within 90 days".<span class="line"><!---->I understand they aim to publish "within 90 days".<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Note: I haven't had a chance to read the paper, so just going off the question from adetaylor@ in c#0.<span class="line"><!---->Note: I haven't had a chance to read the paper, so just going off the question from adetaylor@ in c#0.<!----></span><br><br>TL;DR: Nothing new here.<span class="line"><!---->TL;DR: Nothing new here.<!----></span><br><br>> * We also lump together extensions into a single renderer process, and so they were able to steal passwords from LastPass by writing a malicious extension.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; * We also lump together extensions into a single renderer process, and so they were able to steal passwords from LastPass by writing a malicious extension.<!----></span><br><br>This is really the same as the previous bullet.  At their core here, extensions are very akin to origins in this situation.  Lumping them together makes them vulnerable to spectre-like attacks.  And using LastPass as an example isn't really different than using<span class="line"><!---->This is really the same as the previous bullet.  At their core here, extensions are very akin to origins in this situation.  Lumping them together makes them vulnerable to spectre-like attacks.  And using LastPass as an example isn't really different than using<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>passwords.google.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://passwords.google.com"><!---->passwords.google.com<!----></a> - in both cases, if we happen to lump origins (either web pages or extensions) together, there's a risk of leaking data.<span class="line"><!----> - in both cases, if we happen to lump origins (either web pages or extensions) together, there's a risk of leaking data.<!----></span><br><br>We've chatted in the past about different ways we might potentially address this - essentially, trying to be "smarter" about which extensions we join together.  We've come up with a few different ideas - grouping extensions based on install source (e.g. policy installed together, component together, user-installed together), allowing extensions to specify a key in their manifest (`"isolate_me": true`), etc.  We haven't found anything that is scalable and also solved the majority of cases, so haven't invested heavily in it (though I'd still be supportive).<span class="line"><!---->We've chatted in the past about different ways we might potentially address this - essentially, trying to be "smarter" about which extensions we join together.  We've come up with a few different ideas - grouping extensions based on install source (e.g. policy installed together, component together, user-installed together), allowing extensions to specify a key in their manifest (`"isolate_me": true`), etc.  We haven't found anything that is scalable and also solved the majority of cases, so haven't invested heavily in it (though I'd still be supportive).<!----></span><br><br>I also vaguely thought we were looking at different ways we could identify "high value" origins in general, and avoid having those share processes (or be stricter about what's allowed to share with them) - is there still work on that front?  If so, it seems like we could just include extensions in that mechanism (and, ideally, things would "just work").<span class="line"><!---->I also vaguely thought we were looking at different ways we could identify "high value" origins in general, and avoid having those share processes (or be stricter about what's allowed to share with them) - is there still work on that front?  If so, it seems like we could just include extensions in that mechanism (and, ideally, things would "just work").<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I haven't read the full paper in depth yet, but skimming over there is one worrisome part - they claim they can extract HttpOnly cookies from the renderer process memory:<span class="line"><!---->I haven't read the full paper in depth yet, but skimming over there is one worrisome part - they claim they can extract HttpOnly cookies from the renderer process memory:<!----></span><br><br>"Next, as the user was previously authenticated through the university’s single sign-on screen, the housing’s portal iframe automatically accessed the university’s HttpOnly login cookie,  ringing it to the memory address space of the renderer process, without any user interaction."<span class="line"><!---->"Next, as the user was previously authenticated through the university’s single sign-on screen, the housing’s portal iframe automatically accessed the university’s HttpOnly login cookie,  ringing it to the memory address space of the renderer process, without any user interaction."<!----></span><br><br>If this is correct, then we likely have a bug on our hands as we don't allow renderers to access HttpOnly cookies.<span class="line"><!---->If this is correct, then we likely have a bug on our hands as we don't allow renderers to access HttpOnly cookies.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I also haven't read the full paper yet, but I'm curious if we could ask the authors for deanonymized links to their code?  The paper already includes all the authors' names, so I'm assuming they aren't worried about anonymity w.r.t. Chrome, and it might be useful for us to try out some of the links they mention (e.g., <span class="line"><!---->I also haven't read the full paper yet, but I'm curious if we could ask the authors for deanonymized links to their code?  The paper already includes all the authors' names, so I'm assuming they aren't worried about anonymity w.r.t. We've considered various ways of grouping different kinds of extensions in separate processes (privileges, source, etc.), but this hasn't been prioritized so far.  I thought we had a bug filed for that, but so far I can't find it.  We will soon have a new mechanism with SiteInstanceGroups (<span class="line"><!---->.  We've considered various ways of grouping different kinds of extensions in separate processes (privileges, source, etc.), but this hasn't been prioritized so far.  I thought we had a bug filed for that, but so far I can't find it.  We will soon have a new mechanism with SiteInstanceGroups (<!----></span>issue 1195535<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1195535" title="Implement SiteInstance groups"><!---->issue 1195535<!----></a>), which might allow doing this quite easily.<span class="line"><!---->), which might allow doing this quite easily.<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>Re: avoiding process sharing for "high-value" origins within a particular site: in general, our hands are tied by document.domain compatibility, but we've recently shipped Origin-Agent-Cluster (<span class="line"><!---->Re: avoiding process sharing for "high-value" origins within a particular site: in general, our hands are tied by document.domain compatibility, but we've recently shipped Origin-Agent-Cluster (<!----></span>https://web.dev/origin-agent-cluster/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://web.dev/origin-agent-cluster/"><!---->https://web.dev/origin-agent-cluster/<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> M89+) which allows origins to opt-in to origin-level (rather than site-level) isolation (and willingly opt out of using document.domain).  Origins can also hint at this and get stronger protection with COOP+COEP headers (<span class="line"><!----> M89+) which allows origins to opt-in to origin-level (rather than site-level) isolation (and willingly opt out of using document.domain).  Origins can also hint at this and get stronger protection with COOP+COEP headers (<!----></span>https://web.dev/coop-coep/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://web.dev/coop-coep/"><!---->https://web.dev/coop-coep/<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Cc:<strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          caseq@chromium.org jarhar@chromium.org yangguo@chromium.org

      <div class="issue-diff">

          <strong><!---->Cc:</strong>

      </div><br>
    
        
      
        The paper's authors have confirmed that we only leak HttpOnly cookies to the renderer if DevTools had been previously opened.<span class="line"><!---->The paper's authors have confirmed that we only leak HttpOnly cookies to the renderer if DevTools had been previously opened.<!----></span><br><br>Adding some DevTools folks: caseq@, jarhar@, or yangguo@, can you confirm whether this is expected, and share any thoughts about fixing it?  Basically, the paper shared with us here shows how to use Spectre to leak HttpOnly cookies to a same-site cross-origin document in the same process.<span class="line"><!---->Adding some DevTools folks: caseq@, jarhar@, or yangguo@, can you confirm whether this is expected, and share any thoughts about fixing it?  Basically, the paper shared with us here shows how to use Spectre to leak HttpOnly cookies to a same-site cross-origin document in the same process.<!----></span><br><br>I found <span class="line"><!---->I found <!----></span>issue 849483<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=849483" title="DevTools: instrument network events from the browser process"><!---->issue 849483<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>where the description includes "stop routing sensitive data (e.g. HTTP-only cookies) through renderer", so it seems like this is a known issue?  That issue is marked fixed, but with a final comment by jarhar@ "We don't currently have any more plans to move network instrumentation from the renderer process to the browser process", so it's a bit unclear what has and hasn't been fixed, and what the current state of HttpOnly cookies with DevTools is (and whether we need to file a new bug for this).<span class="line"><!---->where the description includes "stop routing sensitive data (e.g. HTTP-only cookies) through renderer", so it seems like this is a known issue?  That issue is marked fixed, but with a final comment by jarhar@ "We don't currently have any more plans to move network instrumentation from the renderer process to the browser process", so it's a bit unclear what has and hasn't been fixed, and what the current state of HttpOnly cookies with DevTools is (and whether we need to file a new bug for this).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>

          Comment 9<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1199865#c9">Comment 9<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

        It looks like the <span class="line"><!---->It looks like the <!----></span>issue 849483<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=849483" title="DevTools: instrument network events from the browser process"><!---->issue 849483<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>has been closed a bit prematurely (re-opened that now). While the new instrumentation has actually been implemented, we're apparently still reporting the raw headers to renderer as well. I've no idea why this hasn't been removed back then, but I assume it might have been left temporarily for compatibility reasons (jarhar@ may have more context here). I think we should be able to drop URLResponseHead::raw_request_response_info altogether now.<span class="line"><!---->has been closed a bit prematurely (re-opened that now). While the new instrumentation has actually been implemented, we're apparently still reporting the raw headers to renderer as well. I've no idea why this hasn't been removed back then, but I assume it might have been left temporarily for compatibility reasons (jarhar@ may have more context here). I think we should be able to drop URLResponseHead::raw_request_response_info altogether now.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        HttpOnly cookies should only be sent over the secure Network.*ExtraInfo CDP events, right...?<span class="line"><!---->HttpOnly cookies should only be sent over the secure Network.*ExtraInfo CDP events, right...?<!----></span><br>Upon further inspection, I found that Network.responseReceived actually includes HttpOnly cookies...<span class="line"><!---->Upon further inspection, I found that Network.responseReceived actually includes HttpOnly cookies...<!----></span><br><br>Since we are already excluding cookies for cross origin requests as of <span class="line"><!---->Since we are already excluding cookies for cross origin requests as of <!----></span>issue 868407<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=868407" title="Network panel show &quot;Provisional headers are shown&quot; for all non-same origin requests' request headers"><!---->issue 868407<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>I figured HttpOnly cookies would have also been excluded - I guess I was wrong.<span class="line"><!---->I figured HttpOnly cookies would have also been excluded - I guess I was wrong.<!----></span><br>I think it would make sense to start excluding HttpOnly cookies from Network.responseRecieved now, since we should already be getting them in the secure Network.*ExtraInfo requests.<span class="line"><!---->I think it would make sense to start excluding HttpOnly cookies from Network.responseRecieved now, since we should already be getting them in the secure Network.*ExtraInfo requests.<!----></span><br><br>Removing report_raw_headers, which I created <span class="line"><!---->Removing report_raw_headers, which I created <!----></span>issue 1017836<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1017836" title="Remove report_raw_headers from network::ResourceRequest"><!---->issue 1017836<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>to track, is blocked by <span class="line"><!---->to track, is blocked by <!----></span>issue 1004979<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1004979" title="DevTools: Shared worker main script and subresource requests do not emit Network.*ExtraInfo events"><!---->issue 1004979<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>which is that shared workers aren't fully instrumented like service workers and don't get the ExtraInfo events, which means that they need report_raw_headers in order to get more useful headers.<span class="line"><!---->which is that shared workers aren't fully instrumented like service workers and don't get the ExtraInfo events, which means that they need report_raw_headers in order to get more useful headers.<!----></span><br><br>I started working on shared worker instrumentation but it became an enormous refactor I never quite completed. We could probably just remove report_raw_headers since it's not that likely anyone actually cares about more accurate headers for shared worker requests anyway...<span class="line"><!---->I started working on shared worker instrumentation but it became an enormous refactor I never quite completed. We could probably just remove report_raw_headers since it's not that likely anyone actually cares about more accurate headers for shared worker requests anyway...<!----></span><br><br>tldr:<span class="line"><!---->tldr:<!----></span><br>We can either filter out HttpOnly cookies from Network.responseReceived when report_raw_headers is enabled which shouldn't break anything, OR we could delete report_raw_headers entirely, which could theoretically lose DevTools some headers for shared worker network requests.<span class="line"><!---->We can either filter out HttpOnly cookies from Network.responseReceived when report_raw_headers is enabled which shouldn't break anything, OR we could delete report_raw_headers entirely, which could theoretically lose DevTools some headers for shared worker network requests.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Apr 28, 2021, 11:55 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        It looks like disabling report_raw_headers would be more challenging than I thought:<span class="line"><!---->It looks like disabling report_raw_headers would be more challenging than I thought:<!----></span><br>1. Network.responseReceived's securityState and securityDetails appear to only be reported when report_raw_headers is true, so we would either have to report this from the network stack regardless of report_raw_headers, or move it to Network.responseReceivedExtraInfo [1].<span class="line"><!---->1. Network.responseReceived's securityState and securityDetails appear to only be reported when report_raw_headers is true, so we would either have to report this from the network stack regardless of report_raw_headers, or move it to Network.responseReceivedExtraInfo [1].<!----></span><br>2. It appears that the response HTTP status code can change based on report_raw_headers [1]? I suppose we would also need to move that to Network.responseReceivedExtraInfo...<span class="line"><!---->2. It appears that the response HTTP status code can change based on report_raw_headers [1]? I suppose we would also need to move that to Network.responseReceivedExtraInfo...<!----></span><br>3. The last time I checked, due to the way Puppeteer is architected, it doesn't use Network.*ExtraInfo CDP events, which means that it is completely relying on report_raw_headers for just about everything, and removing it would definitely make its users unhappy. The reason it can't use ExtraInfo events is because not every request that chrome "makes" actually includes ExtraInfo events - the ones which don't make it all the way to the network stack or stay in the renderer don't get these events. In order for this to be addressed, Puppeteer should probably be using the CDP Fetch domain or something instead...? Maybe we could work around this by letting Puppeteer use report_raw_headers while making chrome not use report_raw_headers...?<span class="line"><!---->3. The last time I checked, due to the way Puppeteer is architected, it doesn't use Network.*ExtraInfo CDP events, which means that it is completely relying on report_raw_headers for just about everything, and removing it would definitely make its users unhappy. The reason it can't use ExtraInfo events is because not every request that chrome "makes" actually includes ExtraInfo events - the ones which don't make it all the way to the network stack or stay in the renderer don't get these events. In order for this to be addressed, Puppeteer should probably be using the CDP Fetch domain or something instead...? Maybe we could work around this by letting Puppeteer use report_raw_headers while making chrome not use report_raw_headers...?<!----></span><br><br>The other option, which would exclude HttpOnly cookies from the raw response info sent back to the renderer, requires more knowledge of the network stack than I have. It looks like we could filter them out here [2], but I don't know how to take an actual string of header information, parse the cookies out if it, and determine if each cookie was HttpOnly or not...<span class="line"><!---->The other option, which would exclude HttpOnly cookies from the raw response info sent back to the renderer, requires more knowledge of the network stack than I have. It looks like we could filter them out here [2], but I don't know how to take an actual string of header information, parse the cookies out if it, and determine if each cookie was HttpOnly or not...<!----></span><br><br>I also want to make sure I understand the issue completely:<span class="line"><!---->I also want to make sure I understand the issue completely:<!----></span><br><br>> The paper's authors have confirmed that we only leak HttpOnly cookies to the renderer if DevTools had been previously opened.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; The paper's authors have confirmed that we only leak HttpOnly cookies to the renderer if DevTools had been previously opened.<!----></span><br><br>> Basically, the paper shared with us here shows how to use Spectre to leak HttpOnly cookies to a same-site cross-origin document in the same process.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; Basically, the paper shared with us here shows how to use Spectre to leak HttpOnly cookies to a same-site cross-origin document in the same process.<!----></span><br><br>I understand that allowing HttpOnly cookies into the renderer is a problem in and of itself, but what exactly is a "same-site cross-origin document" and how does it affect the scenario? Is HttpOnly cookies in a renderer process for its own site the *only* concern here?<span class="line"><!---->I understand that allowing HttpOnly cookies into the renderer is a problem in and of itself, but what exactly is a "same-site cross-origin document" and how does it affect the scenario? Is HttpOnly cookies in a renderer process for its own site the *only* concern here?<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://test-results.appspot.com/data/layout_results/linux-rel/677426/blink_web_tests%20%28with%20patch%29/layout-test-results/results.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://test-results.appspot.com/data/layout_results/linux-rel/677426/blink_web_tests%20%28with%20patch%29/layout-test-results/results.html"><!---->https://test-results.appspot.com/data/layout_results/linux-rel/677426/blink_web_tests%20%28with%20patch%29/layout-test-results/results.html<!----></a><br>[2] <span class="line"><!---->[2] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:services/network/url_loader.cc;l=339-355;drc=221e331b49dfefadbc6fa40b0c68e6f97606d0b3<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:services/network/url_loader.cc;l=339-355;drc=221e331b49dfefadbc6fa40b0c68e6f97606d0b3"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:services/network/url_loader.cc;l=339-355;drc=221e331b49dfefadbc6fa40b0c68e6f97606d0b3<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I am still working on removing report_raw_headers here: <span class="line"><!---->I am still working on removing report_raw_headers here: <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2856099<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2856099"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2856099<!----></a><br>I also have another patch which should help puppeteer move off of report_raw_headers: <span class="line"><!---->I also have another patch which should help puppeteer move off of report_raw_headers: <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2898747<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2898747"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2898747<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/7d3da352d7833e4e8966c87321ef063f9d0dad31<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/7d3da352d7833e4e8966c87321ef063f9d0dad31"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/7d3da352d7833e4e8966c87321ef063f9d0dad31<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>7d3da352d7833e4e8966c87321ef063f9d0dad31<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/7d3da352d7833e4e8966c87321ef063f9d0dad31"><!---->7d3da352d7833e4e8966c87321ef063f9d0dad31<!----></a><br>Author: Joey Arhar <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Joey Arhar &lt;<!----></span>jarhar@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/jarhar@chromium.org"><!---->jarhar@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Tue Aug 03 22:32:36 2021<span class="line"><!---->Date: Tue Aug 03 22:32:36 2021<!----></span><br><br>[DevTools] Remove report_raw_headers from network::ResourceRequest<span class="line"><!---->[DevTools] Remove report_raw_headers from network::ResourceRequest<!----></span><br><br>This patch also removes raw response info from<span class="line"><!---->This patch also removes raw response info from<!----></span><br>network::mojom::URLResponseHead.<span class="line"><!---->network::mojom::URLResponseHead.<!----></span><br><br>report_raw_headers has been used by DevTools to get "raw" headers for<span class="line"><!---->report_raw_headers has been used by DevTools to get "raw" headers for<!----></span><br>network request debugging. However, the renderer process shouldn't have<span class="line"><!---->network request debugging. However, the renderer process shouldn't have<!----></span><br>access to raw headers, because then it would have access to cross-origin<span class="line"><!---->access to raw headers, because then it would have access to cross-origin<!----></span><br>cookies, HttpOnly cookies, etc.<span class="line"><!---->cookies, HttpOnly cookies, etc.<!----></span><br><br>In order to fix this security issue but still make headers debuggable<span class="line"><!---->In order to fix this security issue but still make headers debuggable<!----></span><br>for DevTools, a trusted channel to the DevTools frontend which goes<span class="line"><!---->for DevTools, a trusted channel to the DevTools frontend which goes<!----></span><br>through the browser process instead of the renderer process was made,<span class="line"><!---->through the browser process instead of the renderer process was made,<!----></span><br>and I plumbed an ID, called "devtools_request_id", through this channel<span class="line"><!---->and I plumbed an ID, called "devtools_request_id", through this channel<!----></span><br>in<span class="line"><!---->in<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/648335<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/648335"><!---->crrev.com/648335<!----></a> so DevTools has required context to debug the<span class="line"><!----> so DevTools has required context to debug the<!----></span><br>network request.<span class="line"><!---->network request.<!----></span><br><br>Now that DevTools doesn't need report_raw_headers in order to debug<span class="line"><!---->Now that DevTools doesn't need report_raw_headers in order to debug<!----></span><br>network headers anymore, we're removing it along with the related raw<span class="line"><!---->network headers anymore, we're removing it along with the related raw<!----></span><br>header code in order to simplify things and strengthen security.<span class="line"><!---->header code in order to simplify things and strengthen security.<!----></span><br><br>I waited longer than I should have to do this because shared worker<span class="line"><!---->I waited longer than I should have to do this because shared worker<!----></span><br>request debugging still relies on report_raw_headers, but in light of<span class="line"><!---->request debugging still relies on report_raw_headers, but in light of<!----></span><br>recent security issues, in addition to lack of perceived interest in<span class="line"><!---->recent security issues, in addition to lack of perceived interest in<!----></span><br>shared worker request debugging, and *significant* complexity of<span class="line"><!---->shared worker request debugging, and *significant* complexity of<!----></span><br>updating shared worker code, I am going for it now.<span class="line"><!---->updating shared worker code, I am going for it now.<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1142014<span         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
